content: The "Estate Tax Relief Act of 2003" is also known as the Reduction of Estate Tax Rates. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2003, also known as the Reduction of Estate Tax Rates, amends Section 2001 of the Internal Revenue Code by changing the computation of tax to be a percentage of the excess of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts over the total tax paid on gifts made after December 31, 1976. The applicable percentage is based on the highest tax rate for the year of the decedent's death or gift. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2003 amends the Internal Revenue Code by changing the computation of tax to be based on the excess of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts. The tax is calculated on the sum of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts, with the applicable percentage based on the highest tax rate for the year of the decedent's death or gift. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2003 amends the Internal Revenue Code to calculate tax based on the excess of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts. The tax is based on the sum of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts, with the applicable percentage determined by the highest tax rate for the year of the decedent's death or gift. Section 2502 of the Code is also amended to reflect these changes. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2003 amends the Internal Revenue Code to calculate tax based on the excess of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts. Section 2502 states that the tax imposed for each calendar year is based on the sum of taxable gifts, with the donor being responsible for payment. Amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after the enactment of the Act. Unified credit against estate and gift taxes increased to exclusion equivalent of $10,000,000; inflation adjustment of credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the applicable credit amount to $10,000,000 for estate and gift taxes. An inflation adjustment provision is also added for decedents dying or gifts made after 2003. The applicable credit amount for estate and gift taxes is increased to $10,000,000 with an inflation adjustment provision for decedents dying or gifts made after 2003. The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying, and gifts made, after the date of the enactment of this Act. Repeal of estate tax benefit for family-owned business interests under Section 2057 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with conforming amendments and effective date for estates of decedents dying after the enactment of the Act.
